content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Perfect!

Hi,

In the validator 5, the first line that represents the buttons is shifted by one character compared to the other lines.

I did not spend too much time looking at this since it looks great and I want to try this when it's out!
What I did notice is that there may be multiple correct answers to each input.
I checked on Validator 1. 
That one should have 0 1 and 0 2 with the same amount of rotations.

Depending on how users check and replace ( new > previousBest OR new >= previousBest) you may fail them even though they were correct.

This could be solved by adjusting the wording to find the first button with the highest rotation count.

I feel like a great part of the difficulty of this puzzle resides on the tests themselves. I found it very annoying to have to look at each of the steps of a 3x3 (or 1x10) array to find one small mistakes in the implementation. 

Probably my approach wasn't ideal but I would have loved some small tests at the beginning, specially because in this puzzle manually setting up test cases faces up the problem of python trimming strings ...

Just so I don't only criticize, I suggest this one testcase (basically an easier version of the 2nd test):
1
4
       |    |    |  
  +----+  --+  --+  
  |                 
0 1
5

It did help me find a bug in my directions' logic.

Also, my current solution passes all tests but not the last validator, which apparently is the more demanding one. Since I don't think I did anything particularly clever, people might face this issue once the puzzle is approved. So I'd also suggest to separate the last test/validator pair into two pairs of similar performance requirement.
I do not get how the rotation works. What does it mean to rotate a button?
Love it !
very cool

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Really nice puzzle! Statement is clear and concise. Test cases are robust, even pushing the optimization boundary. I thoroughly enjoyed this puzzle. Great work!

Clever puzzle! Nice job. A couple of things:

- I like title case for the title of a puzzle. Consider "Chain Reaction".

- I'm seeing anticlockwise and anti-clockwise on the Internet, but I'm not seeing the two words separated being proper. You have two different versions in the last paragraph of your goal. I believe your should probably just push the two words together for consistency throughout your goal.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: good game

Hey CodinGamer! Your contribution has unfortunately not been moderated on time and will temporarily be removed from the system... But no worries! You can republish it anytime to give it another chance! :)

At least in US English "Anti-clockwise" is usually "Counter-clockwise".  For fun, and people who don't use sun-dial based clocks with hands, another word for the same thing is "widdershins".
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Widdershins

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: I had fun solving it. Seemed fairly easy conceptually, probably easier than some other medium puzzles on CG. Writing down conditions for triggering buttons was probably the crucial part. Recognising the shapes from ASCII was a nice exercise. There's a bit of a gotcha when you go from the "Validator 2" test to "More rotations", which may or may not be obvious ;) [details in my previous comment]

Finally solved it!

I was initially stuck only passing first 4 tests and couldn't quite figure out why.
Turned out in each move I was rotating all the affected buttons, including doing it more than once if a given button was triggered by more than one other button. Great recipe for an infinite loop ;) De-duping the list solved the issue. 

Would be awesome to have a test which would lead to similar issue and small enough to 'track the execution' manually.

Nice puzzle! Other than wasting time and brain cycles because of my silly bug, it was fun. Kinda wish there was a 'warning' in the description that each button can only be triggered once in a given cycle. It hindsight, seems quite obvious though. Maybe figuring it out is part of the puzzle?

Thanks!
I believe the Validator 2 has an incorrect number of buttons - it says 10, but actually 15 are drawn.
There is missing a space in the first line of the test "even more rotations". My parser didn't work.

My first approach was to but the next buttons to rotate in a list and then keep picking from that list. But then the buttons are rotated one after the other and the order of inserting is important. It didn't pass any tests, so my guess is that they need to turn simultaneously.
If this is important, it should be mentioned in the description.
At first I also missed the fact that the direction is alternating.

Goal section
* The last sentence: What is the word for "sens" in English?
* The last sentence: Do you mean "alternating" instead of "alterning"?

Input section
* Please change "int" to "integer" (twice).

Output section
* Please change "int" to "integer".

Thanks.

You're always there to help, many thanks again ! 
I edited the wording for the last sentence and fixed the "int" situation :)

Yes, at each step, all triggered buttons turn simultaneously, which may trigger other buttons in the next step. Figuring it out is kind of part of the puzzle, but I'll add some clarifications.
Thanks for the feedback !
Thanks, I didn't notice since my code worked anyway... I corrected the test :)
I've corrected the mistake, thanks !
Thanks for your feedback and approval, glad you liked it ! :)
Thanks for the approval !
Thanks for the feedback, I corrected the statement.
Picture it like an oven button but with legs that can connect with others buttons' legs. There's an example in the statement that should help you understand.

Thanks for the feedback !
I added a warm up test as you suggested. I also added an extra test for the 10k rotations :)
Good point, I overlooked the possibility because it's highly unlikely as the number of rotations grows, but that might happen in the very first tests...
Hi, thanks, I corrected the validator !

I just ran all the new test cases through my Python code and passed them all. I'm slowest on test case 11, but never more than 2700 ms which is no more than about 1/2 way to the timeout limit.

I was sitting in a hotel lobby last weekend at 5am thinking about how I would capture and represent these buttons in my code. For me, crafting a data structure for these buttons was more challenging than many other puzzles. Once I had the bugs worked out of my data structure, the rest came together nicely.

Thanks for the new tests. There seems to be missing a space in the first line of validator 5.

Now I can't pass val 5 (with the extra space fixed), test 6 and val 6, which is great since at least the player would know by test 6 that a more performant solution is required.

Good job. Now it's time for me to improve my solution :D
Nice catch! I only use the second and third row of the buttons, so I totally missed that.
Thanks for replying. I was looking at the example. Where is the pivot of the button? If it is the + it does not seem to work.
Yes, the pivot is the +

If you rotate the example |
                                              +-- 
90 degrees clockwise then the long leg should come to the right of the + and the two smaller ones should point downwards, or?

Actually there's no long or short legs, it's just that horizontally a leg is represented by -- and vertically by |
And yes, in your example, the one on the top ends on the right and the one on the right at the bottom, which makes:
+--
|

So there are two identical legs with equal length and just the representation is different. For some reason I thought based on the representation that they are of different lengths and only the longer ones make contact. 
Thanks for clarifying this.
